Out there beyond the horizon...past the crashing
tumult of the surf...undulating on the ocean
surface...lie large soups of trash.

The pacific ocean hosts two of five of these
human-made collections of garbage.

Each of which is the result of currents called
gyres gathering the 8 million metric tons
of trash that flow into the ocean annually.

These gyres are the trash compactors of the
ocean.

They loosely collect the ocean’s trash all
into five giant areas.

But imagine if there was a way to actually
clean up these massive amounts of waste by
simply buying a bracelet.
It turns out there is.

Two Florida surfers created a company called
4ocean to do exactly that.

They sell bracelets to fund a large-scale
ocean cleanup effort.

But can purchasing a recycled glass and plastic
bracelet actually translate into less trash
in the ocean?

Today, I’m going to ask a simple question:
is 4ocean legit?

More specifically, is what they say they do
(using revenue from bracelets to clean up
ocean trash) actually happening?

The core of 4Ocean’s operating model lies
in one big difference from many other ocean

conservation or clean-up groups: it’s a
for-profit company.

Co-founder Andrew Cooper explains this decision
to keep 4ocean a for-profit as an opportunity

to show the moral capability of the private
sector: “Everything around you is brought

to you by the private sector, why can’t
the private sector do more good?

Why can’t we create a company, a for-profit,
that can do good, that’s mission-driven…

We really wanted to break the model and to
challenge ourselves and challenge the private
sector.”

Essentially, 4ocean has managed to leverage
their bracelets (which are made from recycled

materials but not necessarily the exact trash
is taken from the ocean) to create a number
of clean-up operations.

Unlike other companies based loosely around
causes--like Patagonia, Toms or Tesla--4ocean

seeks to put their trash clean-up mission
first and their products second.

Their central claim is that for every bracelet
you buy, 1 pound of trash gets cleaned up
from the ocean.
And yes, 4ocean definitely does clean up trash.

They’ve hired over 300 employees, 100 of
which are full-time that help collect garbage

with the three B’s: “Boots, boats, and
booms.

So that’s boots on the ground, on the beaches,
boats on the water, and booms at river mouths.”

They also host community events for people
to volunteer and learn about the ocean trash
epidemic.

But 4ocean is adamant in their claim that
the trash volunteers collect doesn’t count
towards their “pull a pound” promise.

Over the past two years, Cooper claims that
4ocean has cleaned up over 6 million pounds

(2.7 million kg) of trash from the ocean according
to their internal calculator.

They then take all of this garbage, sort it,
recycle that which can be recycled, incinerate

some of the garbage that can’t, and find
other solutions for the rest, like sending

tires to a devulcanization plant for reuse
on playgrounds.

In short, 4ocean definitely seems to be cleaning
up trash from the oceans.

A fact which the third party Better Business
Bureau audits every couple of months by matching
receipts to trash counts.

As of right now, the company has received
an A+. 4ocean is even working on a “link

on the website where you can click the trash
tracker and you can search by location and

by date, and you can look at ‘March 16th,
2017’, what did 4ocean clean up, what did
it look like, what were the contents?”

But as much good as 4ocean’s clean-up efforts
do, it’s still just a band-aid solution

to a systemic problem, a fact that Cooper
readily admits: “4ocean is not about the
number of bracelets we sell…

Bracelet sales will never be the solution
to removing plastic from the ocean.

It’s a movement that is going to require
everyone in the world’s participation.

Specifically, the decision-makers of the world
that are in charge of waste management infrastructure
and plastic packaging.”

As a result, 4ocean has recently started to
leverage its brand to influence companies

and municipalities in what they call their
upstream approach.

4ocean partnered with Air Canada to eliminate
all of its single-use plastics on its aircraft

and is now in the process of working with
two local government bodies to create better
waste management systems.

That being said, Cooper stressed that their
relationships with these two municipalities
are currently tentative.

Admittedly, when I initially started this
research process I was wary of 4Ocean in large

part because they seemed to lack a needed
amount of transparency especially when it

came to where the revenue from the bracelets
actually went.

Considering that each bracelet retails for
$20, it seemed like there should be more clarity

around how that considerable amount of money
is used.

After two years, Cooper says the company is
honing in on transparency and messaging.

Indeed, Cooper was more than willing to share
details about financials: “Just to be transparent,
we’ve sold 4.2 million bracelets.

We very recently, like within the past couple
of weeks released our personal tax returns

and all of our business financials to the
Better Business Bureau to be a third party

verifier that Alex and I have each only paid
ourself .7% of all the revenue generated from
day one.”

And according to Cooper that revenue rings
in north of 50 million dollars.

All of the rest of that 98.6% gets put back
into the company in form of R&D for their

new line of products, administration, infrastructure,
supply chain research, and wages for their

clean-up crews, whom according to Cooper,
earn a living wage, but the wages are relative

to where employees live, so they could vary
wildly.

With all of this in mind, I think it is still
important to stay vigilant about financials.

While it is notable that Cooper shared part
of their finances, it’s even more important
that back they back up these claims with data.

4ocean needs to earn the trust of its customers
not through ads, digital marketing, or words,

but through transparent communication and
action.

If done right, like in the case of Ecosia,
who publish a monthly detailed breakdown of

their financial reports and tree planting
receipts, it would be way easier to spend
that $20 with a clear conscience.

At the end of the day, over 6 million pounds
(2.7 million kg) of trash is an impressive

feat to clean up, but considering that over
17 billion pounds (8 billion kg) of plastic

enter the ocean each year, 4ocean’s tally
is unfortunately just a drop in the bucket.

The fact that that this two-year-old company
seems to be not only thinking about the downstream

effects of plastic, but also the upstream
sources of it, is encouraging.

In terms of transparency, Cooper made clear
that they are trying hard to show that they

are not just talking the talk, but are also
walking the walk.

He even went so far as to suggest: “If the
Better Business Bureau isn’t the best one,

I’d like to hear people in the comments
suggest one that’s better, and we’re open
to partner with them.

We literally want to offer as much transparency
as possible.”

So, at the end of the day, yes, the money
from their bracelets is contributing to ocean

clean-up efforts and advocacy work trying
to minimize plastic consumption and waste.

But that’s not to say 4ocean is the only
option.

There are plenty of nonprofits like The Ocean
Cleanup or the Surfrider Foundation that are
doing similar work.
So, it’s important to do your research.

There are other videos and guides that together
can help you make an informed decision.

And it’s also key continue having conversations
about whether for-profit companies can ever
fix a capitalist structural problem.

In other words, can the private sector reform
from the inside out?

If the answer is no, then it’s important
to mindfully navigate our relationship to
companies like 4ocean.
